snippet.description: How does the x-component of a vector field relate to the divergence?
snippet.title: Divergence formula, part 1

snippet.description: Here we finish the line of reasoning which leads to the formula for divergence in two dimensions.
snippet.title: Divergence formula, part 2

snippet.description: An example of computing and interpreting the divergence of a two-dimensional vector field.
snippet.title: Divergence example

snippet.description: Learn how divergence is expressed using the same upsidedown triangle symbols that the gradient uses.
snippet.title: Divergence notation

snippet.description: A description of how vector fields relate to fluid rotation, laying the intuition for what the operation of curl represents.
snippet.title: 2d curl intuition

snippet.description: Here we build up to the formula for computing the two-dimensional curl of a vector field, reasoning through what partial derivative information corresponds to fluid rotation.
snippet.title: 2d curl formula

snippet.description: A worked example of computing and interpreting two-dimensional curl.
snippet.title: 2d curl example

snippet.description: The meaning of positive curl in a fluid flow can sometimes look a bit different from the clear cut rotation-around-a-point examples discussed in previous videos.
snippet.title: 2d curl nuance

snippet.description: Learn how a three-dimensional vector can be used to describe three-dimensional rotation.  This is important for understanding three-dimensional curl.
snippet.title: Describing rotation in 3d with a vector

snippet.description: Here we start transitioning from the understanding of two-dimensional curl into an understanding of three-dimensional curl.
snippet.title: 3d curl intuition, part 1

snippet.description: Continuing the intuition for how three-dimensional curl represents rotation in three-dimensional fluid flow.
snippet.title: 3d curl intuition, part 2

snippet.description: How to compute a three-dimensional curl, imagined as a cross product of sorts.
snippet.title: 3d curl formula, part 1

snippet.description: This finishes the demonstration of how to compute three-dimensional curl using a certain determinant.
snippet.title: 3d curl formula, part 2

snippet.description: A worked example of a three-dimensional curl computation.
snippet.title: 3d curl computation example

snippet.description: A visual understanding for how the Laplace operator is an extension of the second derivative to multivariable functions.
snippet.title: Laplacian intuition

snippet.description: A worked example of computing the laplacian of a two-variable function.
snippet.title: Laplacian computation example

snippet.description: This is another way you might see the Laplace operator written.
snippet.title: Explicit Laplacian formula

snippet.description: If the Laplacian of a function is zero everywhere, it is called Harmonic. Harmonic functions arise all the time in physics, capturing a certain notion of "stability", whenever one point in space is influenced by its neighbors.
snippet.title: Harmonic Functions

snippet.description: Before jumping into the Jacobian, it's important to make sure we all know how to think about matrices geometrically.  This is targetted towards those who have seen linear algebra but may need a quick refresher.
snippet.title: Jacobian prerequisite knowledge

snippet.description: A visual representation of local linearity for a function with a 2d input and a 2d output, in preparation for learning about the Jacobian matrix.
snippet.title: Local linearity for a multivariable function

snippet.description: An introduction to how the jacobian matrix represents what a multivariable function looks like locally, as a linear transformation.
snippet.title: The Jacobian matrix

snippet.description: This finishes the introduction of the Jacobian matrix, working out the computations for the example shown in the last video.
snippet.title: Computing a Jacobian matrix

snippet.description: How to interpret the determinant of a Jacobian matrix, along with some examples.
snippet.title: The Jacobian Determinant

snippet.description: The "tangent plane" of the graph of a function is, well, a two-dimensional plane that is tangent to this graph.  Here you can see what that looks like.
snippet.title: What is a tangent plane

snippet.description: How can you describe a specified plane in space as the graph of a function?
snippet.title: Controlling a plane in space

snippet.description: Here you can see how to use the control over functions whose graphs are planes, as introduced in the last video, to find the tangent plane to a function graph.
snippet.title: Computing a tangent plane

snippet.description: A "local linearization" is the generalization of tangent plane functions; one that can apply to multivariable functions with any number of inputs.
snippet.title: Local linearization

snippet.description: After learning about local linearizations of multivariable functions, the next step is to understand how to approximate a function even more closely with a quadratic approximation.
snippet.title: What do quadratic approximations look like

snippet.description: How to creat a quadratic function that approximates an arbitrary two-variable function.
snippet.title: Quadratic approximation formula, part 1

snippet.description: A continuation from the previous video, leading to the full formula for the quadratic approximation of a two-variable function.
snippet.title: Quadratic approximation formula, part 2

snippet.description: A worked example for finding the quadratic approximation of a two-variable function.
snippet.title: Quadratic approximation example

snippet.description: The Hessian matrix is a way of organizing all the second partial derivative information of a multivariable function.
snippet.title: The Hessian matrix

snippet.description: How to write an expression like ax^2 + bxy + cy^2 using matrices and vectors.
snippet.title: Expressing a quadratic form with a matrix

snippet.description: This is the more general form of a quadratic approximation for a scalar-valued multivariable function.  It is analogous to a quadratic Taylor polynomial in the single-variable world.
snippet.title: Vector form of multivariable quadratic approximation

snippet.description: A description of maxima and minima of multivariable functions, what they look like, and a little bit about how to find them.
snippet.title: Multivariable maxima and minima

snippet.description: Just because the tangent plane to a multivariable function is flat, it doesn't mean that point is a local minimum or a local maximum.  There is a third possibility, new to multivariable calculus, called a "saddle point".
snippet.title: Saddle points

snippet.description: An example of looking for local minima in a multivariable function by finding where tangent planes are flat, along with some of the intuitions that will underly the second partial derivative test.
snippet.title: Warm up to the second partial derivative test

snippet.description: How to determine if the critical point of a two-variable function is a local minimum, a local maximum, or a saddle point.
snippet.title: Second partial derivative test

snippet.description: The second partial derivative test is based on a formula which seems to come out of nowhere.  Here, you can see a little more intuition for why it looks the way it does.
snippet.title: Second partial derivative test intuition

snippet.description: A worked example of finding a classifying critical points of a two-variable function.
snippet.title: Second partial derivative test example, part 1

snippet.description: Continuing the worked example from the previous video, now classifying each critical point.
snippet.title: Second partial derivative test example, part 2

snippet.description: See a simple example of a constrained optimization problem and start getting a feel for how to think about it.  This introduces the topic of Lagrange multipliers.
snippet.title: Constrained optimization introduction

snippet.description: The Lagrange multiplier technique is how we take advantage of the observation made in the last video, that the solution to a constrained optimization problem occurs when the contour lines of the function being maximized are tangent to the constraint curve.
snippet.title: Lagrange multipliers, using tangency to solve constrained optimization

snippet.description: Working out the algebra for the final solution the the example from the previous two videos.
snippet.title: Finishing the intro lagrange multiplier example

snippet.description: A Lagrange multipliers example of maximizing revenues subject to a budgetary constraint.
snippet.title: Lagrange multiplier example, part 1

snippet.description: Finishing off the example from the previous video
snippet.title: Lagrange multiplier example, part 2

snippet.description: How a special function, called the "Lagrangian", can be used to package together all the steps needed to solve a constrained optimization problem.
snippet.title: The Lagrangian

snippet.description: In the previous videos on Lagrange multipliers, the Lagrange multiplier itself has just been some proportionality constant that we didn't care about. Here, you can see what its real meaning is.
snippet.title: Meaning of Lagrange multiplier

snippet.description:
Here, you can see a proof of the fact shown in the last video, that the Lagrange multiplier gives information about how altering a constraint can alter the solution to a constrained maximization problem.  Note, this is somewhat technical

Multivariable Calculus on Khan Academy: Think calculus. Then think algebra II and working with two variables in a single equation. Now generalize and combine these two mathematical concepts, and you begin to see some of what Multivariable calculus entails, only now include multi dimensional thinking. Typical concepts or operations may include: limits and continuity, partial differentiation, multiple integration, scalar functions, and fundamental theorem of calculus in multiple dimensions.
